In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code for the function `timezone_bumper(dt, bump)`:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ErrorException("Date type not allowed. Only DateTime types are accepted."))
    else
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    end
end
```

The function `timezone_bumper` takes a single argument `dt`. If the type of `dt` is `Date`, it throws an error. Otherwise, it increases the timestamp by `bump` hours and returns the new timestamp. The default value for `bump` is 3 hours.
